div.head: BOVRIL
div.p: Qu'est ce que c'est BOVRIL?
BOVRIL est le produit garanti du meilleur bétail qui existe.
C'est un repas à la minute qui protège contre les intempéries.
"BOVRIL" et "Bonne Cuisine" sont deux mots qui disent la même chose.

BOVRIL répond a une nécessité; il est non seulement une boisson delicieuse et saine, mais il est encore indispensable pour préparer instantanement des soupes et sauces appétisantes. Bovril n'a pas de rival pour corser les plats les plus récherches.
BOVRIL répare l'organisme fatigué.

div.head: "L'ALLEMAGNE CEST L'ENNEMI."
div.p: If any reliance could be placed upon the jeremiads of a French contemporary of Cairo our Teutonic brethren are a very perfidious people. They are for ever plotting to cause dissension between two of the Great Powers, England and Russia, the latter of which is France's staunch ally. Far worse than that, they are striving to put obstacles in the way of France's "peaceful penetration" into Morocco, which was her "quid pro quo" for renouncing her secular interests in Egypt. Through Germany's duplicity, France' will have to make new sacrifices to maintain the Algeciras compact. In Macedonia, England's policy is menaced by the Sultan of Turkey's bostihty to reforms. He has assumed an obdurate attitude which would never have been ventured upon but for Germany's covert support, In Persia, likewise, be is being used as a screen for German intrigue. All this would of course be very serious if it were true. But is it true? The answer to that question de-. pends upon testimony; and of testimony she has nothing but the "ipse dixit" of a writer, who builds his theories upon bare surmise. His "facts," or what he maker do duty for. such, are no doubt capable of frightening those who are susceptible to alarm and become easily prey to panic. But for 'men of firm mind and understanding" to employ legal phraseology, such warnings, based upon con jeotures which are purely imaginary, present no fear. On the contrary, they ask themselves why they are urged to believe all these dreadful things. Nations, unlike individuals, never practice knavery out of mere delight in taking advantage of & trusting neighbours. That sort of game in politics does not pay. In other words, honesty has been found, in the long run, to be the best policy. Why then should Germany, Machiavellian as our censor may deem her, adopt some other course 1 He can give no reason, nor anyone else. The real truth, though it pains us to give currency to it, is that certain French journalists, not the most reputable, think to obtain a cheap, popularity by goading at a foreign nation, which has proved itself superior to theirs, cot alone in that conflict, which is the crucial test of manliness, namely the field of battle, but in many departments of intellectual activity, whereof their nation formerly held the supremacy. It is not pleasant to take a back seat or to see oneself ousted by a rival. The practical mind, to be sure, accepts the lesson with due humility, studies the situation in all its bearings, and seeks by avoiding former errors to retrieve the past. But all, men are not endowed with sufficient common sense to take their vicissitudes philosophically Some are ever whining and repining at their ill-success, and casting the blame of their own shortcomings upon the shoulders of others, who they accuse of having adopted Unscrupulous methods to compass their discomfiture lu fact, to maligo '. competitor, whom has worsted you in lifos race affords to mean and superficial intelligen. does a modicum of consolation. We wish our French contemporary joy of his empire-shaking discoveries, which as far as positive proof goods are veritable mare's nests.

div.head: Cholera Bulletin
div.p: The cholera bulletins of the 19th, 20th, and 22nd inst. report 744 deaths at Mecca and 34 deaths at Djeddah.

div.head: Helouan Casino
div.p: On the occasion of the dance to be held at Helouan Casino to-morrow a special train will run from Helowan to Cairo at 1.30 p.m.

div.head: The Brindiel Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P and 0.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at 4.80 o'clock to day:

div.head: British Recreation Club.
div.p: A small dance will take place at this Club on Saturday, 1st February, commencing at 9 p.m. prompt. Members are requested to apply for tickets, price P.T. 20, as early as possible.

div.head: Shepheard's and Ghezireh Palace.
div.p: Shepherd's annual grand ball with cotillon will be held on the 28th inst. and there will as usual, be a fancy dress hall at Ghezireh Palace Casino on Shrove Tuesday, the 3rd of March.

div.head: New Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: Tomorrow night the Door-Leblanc troupe will make their debut at the Alhambra theatre, The programme is well varied and the visit of this illusionist should attract large numbers to the theatre for the few nights that he will be in Alexandria.

div.head: The Calro Season.
div.p: The signs that the Cairo season is to be, after all, a successful one are daily made more evident. The bookings at Shepheard's and Ghezireh Palinee exceed considerably the management's anticipations, and, at the end of this month it is probable that Shepherds will have to refuse applications. Ghezireh Palace, too, is almost overfilled by the arrival of passengers by the "Cedric" the Heliopolis" and the "Caronia,' and in nearly all the hotels the bookings are heavy up to the end of March.

div.head: BEGGING IN CAIRO
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes :

The importunities of European beggars in the streets of Cairo are daily becoming more noticeable, and it is now almost impossible for aby one, more especially visitors, to walk the length of any of our principal streets with out being pestered by these men, who, unlike their pative companions in misfortune, invariably refuse to take no for an answer, and follow one up until the appearance of a policeman, or a refusal of more than ordinary curtness convince them that a retreat is advisable. A number of these men are cripples, and are therefore unable to work, but it is hardly fair to the public that the streets should be made hideous by the display of their infirmities and by the disgraceful manner in which they are allowed to whine for charity. Have the consulates of gugh people no interest in their welfare and no power to alleviate their sufferings except by allowing them to parade the streetski the manner described ? The native beggar 'is to be met with at every turn, but though he frequently bears the marks of visible suffering in a much more noticeable degree than the European, he is at least unobtrusive in his demand for alms, and it is the exception rather than the rule to be followed by one of these after having once refused to notice them. There are now a pumber of exceptionally persistent European boys about Cairo whom it is almost impossible to "shake of unless in possession of a fluent command of thě Arabic language, these boys some of them are little more than children-have every appearance of being well fed and are certainly well clothed, and it is ] astonishing that they should have-escaped the notice of the police for so long a time as they apparently have done. It is hardly likely that these well nourished youngsters are acting without direction, and it should not be difficult for the police to lay their bands upon those who are responsible for their presence in the streets. Some few of them wake a pretence of earning a livelihood by selling matches or other articles of that description, but this is only the usual shallow mask to the worst description of vagrancy with which the more expert of the professional beggars strive to cloak the real nature of their profession, and it is not fair that these lads should hold possession of the payments when there are so many more deserving people, who by reason of this competition are unable to earn the bare livelihood which wopla be otherwise open to them by this means. The public are undoubtedly to blaine in a great measure that this state of things has continued as "long as it has, if some of the residents of - Cairo would compare notes as to who were the least deserving of these street beggars and hand the more persistent of them over to the nearest policeman, they would be doing the whole city a service by ridding them of what bids fit to become a nuisance such as hitherto has only been met with at the church entrances of the Continent.

div.head: THE NATIONALIST PARTY
div.p: Strennous efforts are now being made by Mustapha Pasha Kamel to capture some Irish Nationalist M.P.'s to represent his party in the House of Commons. The recent visit to Cairo of Dr. Rutherford, M P., was a cruel blow to the followers of Kamel, who fully expected that that earnest Radical would allow himself to be patronised by them. But their hopes of: being able to make use of Dr. Rutherford in the House of Commons were cruelly shattered, for that gentleman clearly showed that all his sympathies were with the Constitutional ReEuro League. The Party of Sheikh Aly Youssef won a great victory by inducing Dr Rutber. ford to attend the historic banquet at the Savoy Hotel. The chagrin of the Nationalist Party is extreme. If they do succeed in getting one or two Irish Home Rulere to back them in the House of Commons, we shall be treated to Live-interesting spectacle of two Egyptian parties, each bitterly hostile to the other, forming, as it were, a microonsin of Nationalist politics in Egypt, waging their warfare within the walls of the British Parliament.

div.head: PARTY OF THE PEOPLE.
div.p: The terrific internecine struggles among the members of the Party of the People have resulted in a serious secession for it is said that a considerable following have gone over to the Party of Constitutional Reformers. There still remain, however, a number of stalwarts, who refuse to desert the programme of the late Sheikh M bam-d Abdou and they are determined to carry on their campaign with unremitting energy. Whether this party will ever obtain a bold on Egyptian public opinion is very doubtful The Patty was favoured by Lord Cromer, as is seen by his last Report. It consequently received a great deal of support from the ranks of the higher native officials and at one time seemed to be a power in the land. But as soon as Lord Crmer departed the Party of the People entirely changed its programme. With an utter disregard for political consistency it determined to angle for the support of the populace by attacking LordCromer and the occupation with acrimonious virulence, although up to that time it had been criticised by the Nationaliste for conceiving its orders direct from the British Agency. What precisely was the meaning of this chameleon-like attitude is hard to discover unless it be to make a bid for popularity superior to that of Kainel. It over the Party Wishes to attain to a position of respect in the eyes of any but young Nation slist politicians, this policy of tergiversation will have to be renounced once and for all.

div.head: THE REFORM PARTY.
div.p: The Party of Constitutional Reform is actively engaged in organising its new political headquarters opposite the Turf Club. Their club house is very comfortable and nicely furnished in the European style without any Oriental garishness. The furniture is good and substantial and the sanitary arrangements are excellent. Here may be seen disporting themselves nightly not only the protagonists of Constitutional Reform but also their new friends, the secessionists from the camp of the Sheikh Abdou Party, who bask in cushioned ease and familiarity with their former antagonista.

div.head: THE REPUBLICAN PARTY.
div.p: Not much activity is observable among those Egyptians, who are in favour of Egypt being in mediately declared an independent and autonomous Republic. It is said that they are busily engaged in preparing their programme and drawing up an elaborate series of statutes. The Republicans are also endeavouring surreptitiously. pusly to obtain converts to their creed from all the other parties. It is rumoured that Mustapha Pasha Kamel fears these persons more than any other of his opponents, it was well known that for years his ambition has been to be the first President of the New Republic of Egypt, which only under his guidance would stand a chance of becoming the compeer of Japan as a renascent Oriental state.

div.head: EGYPTIAN LIBERAL PARTY.
div.p: Much comment has been aroused by the silence of Mohamed Bey Wahid, the leader of the Egyptian. Liberal Party. It was fully expected that the chief of the Liberals would have embraced the opportunity of Dr. Rutberford's visit to send that gentleman a lengthy telegram, but as no such telegram has appeared in the columns of the "Progrès" or "Al Mokactam," it is considered that he must be vexed because that M.P. did not visit him when he made a trip to Helonan when he was in Cairo Dr. Rutherford when at Helonan attended the races there instead of paying homage to the Bey. As it was the first time in his life that Dr. Rutherford had ever seen a horse race; it must be concluded that this Unexpected spectacle was so absorbing that he forgot the other and more serious calls upon his time there.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Westcott liner "Joshua Nicholson" sailed from Malta this morning and is due here with general cargo next Sunday morning.

div.head: CASES AGAINST TRAMWAY COMPANY.
div.p: Before the Mixed Court to-day (Judge Herzbruck presiding) was heard an appeal by Mrs. Adams the tenant of the well known 'Cosy Corner' Bar against a decision of the Tribunal of First Instance cancelling her lease for unlawfully sub-letting. Mrs. Adams (who appeared in person and was also legally represented) rigorously asserted that the alleged sub-letting merely consisted in her having put in one Mme Fortunée as 'locum tenens' during her absence in England. The lady in question had no written contract with the appellant and was only her representative, and she had been joined as a co-defendant with the landlord, Ahmed Effendi Selim to obtain her testimony and determine her position. If any sub-letting had taken place it was only of a temporary character and was brought to an end on Mrs. Adam's return from her holiday.

Mme Fortunée, a handsome Armenian in native costume, who appeared in person, bore out Mrs. Adams's statements on being interrogated by the President; and Me Soouffos having replied for Selim Effendi, the judgment was reserved.

div.head: MABROUK V. CIE. DES TRAMWAYS.
div.p: This was a claim for damages brought by an l'injured employé of the defendant company. Me. Mosseri explained at some length that his client, Mabrouk, was one of a gang of | labourers employed in carrying planks at the company's workshops and in receipt of a wage varying from P.T. 6 a day upwards. While so engaged a large slop plank which he was holding at one end escaped from his grasp and falling on his foot injured it 80 severely as to render amputation necessaly. Moreover, counsel stated, the injured man had a mother and two brothers wholly dependent upon him, who have been reduced to poverty by the accident to their relative. A decision given in a similar action in 1898 went to show that the employé in always liable for injuries sustained in course of employment, even where the imprudence of the workman has contributed; the company were bound to take all precautions to ensure the safety of | their employés. It was no answer to say that the victim of the injury should not have been walking backwards as he did. The company were responsible in any case, as the usual wooden rollers should have been used underneath the plank. Me. Carton, replying for the defendants, gave a similar account of the affair, remarking that the distribution of the weight among the 18 men employed, viz. 32 kilos, per man, was not unfair, and that the plank was not a very heavy one. He went out to point out that Mabrouk was actually superintending the operation and should have ordered the men to stop when he felt the plank slipping. The distance traversed being under 80 metres there was no necessity to use wooden pliers. Counsel denied the relevancy of the precedent referred to, which had no application to Egypt. In cases of Simprudence' like the present one the workman nowadays was always held responsible Mr. Mosseri in reply to the court said that the claim was based on want of supervision by the defendants. Case adjourned till next week.

div.head: MME EFTALIA MALTÉZAKI V. CIE. DES TRAMWAYS.
div.p: This action was occasioned by an injury of a more usual but scarcely less serious character. The plaintiff, a married lady residing at Shoubrah had been injured whilst alighting from a tram outside her house on September 15, 1906. Dr. Pietri called in to attend, the lady certified the seriousness of the accident, which was aggravated by the fact of the victim being enceinte. Serious symptoms set in, Me. Zohrab added, and Mme Maltezaki was prematurely confined, as the doctor had predicted, of a delicate and sickly child. All the evidence went to prove that the conductor was in fault in starting the tram before the plaintiff bad alighted, and indeed he had suffered 20 days imprisonment as a result of the police enquiry. Counsel continuing stated that his client was still suffering from hernia as the result of the accident and that Dr. Wildt (appointed by the judge in chambers) reported that an exceedingly delicate surgical operation would be needed to restore her to health. He (Me Zobrab) therefore considered L.E. 2000 not too much to ask by way of compensation. Me Carton objected that the claim rested wholly on groundless allegations, as shewn by the medicalevidence. When plaintiff attempted to get out the car stopped again for her convenience. Dr Pietri's examination shewed that the lady had been injured before ; in mot plaintiff had| had to call in another doctor to substantiate her case, and deceived both by pretending she was in her eighth month instead of her ninth. Dr. Wildt certified that the accouchement was an easy one, that both the mother and child appeared strong and well nourished ; and that the condition of the infant was all that could be desired. As to the pain complained of medical opinion differed, but the majority of the doctors attributed it to a slight wound not caused by the accident alleged. The company were willing to submit the matter to the expert opinion of Dr. Wildt. Judgment was deferred for a week. Another case Nefigsa-bint: Hugsanein . Cie. des Tramways was set down for hearing on April 27. An interesting action brought by the Arte sian Boring Company against the Daira Kasr: el Aly and certain members of the Khedivial family will be reported next week when judgment is to be pronounced.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold urvale responsible for the opinions pr***ed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to partait-within certain necessary Imite free discussion.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN LAND ALLOTMENTS CO.
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, -We shall be obliged if you will permit us to make known through the medium of your columps that request has been drawn up by us to the Directors of The Anglo-Egyptian Land Allotments Co for a return of the unemployed capital of the Company and that the requisition may be signed by all shareholders who like ourselves consider such a course advisable, at the office of Messrs White bead Morris & Co, 14 Sesostris Street. We would remind our fellow shareholders that the Company was promoted two years back with a capital of L B 500,000 having for its object the purebase and improvement of land in Egypt for re-salo Under the chairmansbip of Sir Willian Willoocks whose long experience in this Country and whose acquaintance with Government lands appeared to as a guarantee of adelanto management, the Company seemed to offer every promise of success and principally on the name of the Chairman we Avciated ourselves with the concem It appears, however, that our Directors have never been able to find investment for more than thirty percent of the capital in land in Egypt nor do they appear to have any prospect of further investments in this direction, until the large irrigation scheme of the Government has been completed probably five years hence In the interval the Directors will earn what interest they can on the large invested capital of the Company, most of which will be absorbed in heavy foes of the directorate and management. There remain the investments in Cyprus which we are told will not exceed LE. 150,000. The principal object of the Company having failed we consider that we are entitled to call on our Directors to return as rapidly as possible the capital not permanently invested: there being no doubt that while the shares of the Company are selling at fifty per cent discount the capital is intact Over capitalisation of companies in this country has in a grant measure been the cause of the present rot in the share market, and no COUTBO can possibly improve that market more rapidly than the liberation and retom of uninvested funds. We may add that we are prompted by no feelings of antagonism to our Board who have discussed the position of the Company very frankly with us but they have failed to convince us that they have any prospect of carry. ing out the pmmines of their prospectus. On the other hand they have specified their willingness to meet our request, and return some portion at least of the capital of the Company if the proposal is voted at a general meeting. As the first step in that direction we beg that you will help us to address our co proprietors through your agency and thus give them the opportunity of recovering some of their money as early as possible. We may add that only holders of ordinary shares have any right to vote on this question.
Yours faithfully.
DUKE BAKER FREDK. DODD.
W. WEECH.
W. Eady.

div.head: DR. RUTHERFORD'S VISIT.
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Sir, In common 1 hope with many of your subscribers, I read with much interest the article in your paper of yesterday in which you speed our parting Parliamentary guest, as he returns to his native shores, laden with as much local information as the politicians of the Egyptian party and a crowd of courteous Government officials, could possibly give him in a fortnight. I regret that you did not recommend a return by the long sea journey, as the best way of digesting it all. I hope your article may be read by many of Dr. Rutherford's Parliamentary colleagues, and when they find that he has carried away, not only all the good wishes of his political friends, but that his real has been stimulated, as you say, by the beautiful and costly jewels and treasures which have been bestowed upon him, they will no doubt give him a patient hearing. I hope that any fear of allusions to the spoil. ing of the Egyptians, will not deter him from wearing the above named decorations when he addresses the House. I feel sure that this would be appreciated by the donors, as a proof that the arguments are not lightly used, but given in exchange for value received ; the natives of this country have a strong belief, that no one does much for nothing, and not very much for six pence. My object in writing is to ask you to allow me, through the medium of your columns, to offer a word of warning to Dr. Rutherford's political friends in this country, and that is, that they should leave well alone, lest they should wring from him the involuntary cry of "save me from my friends."
Yours truly,

div.head: PARIS-GENEVA HOUSE.
div.p: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her spring models at the Khedivial Hotel, Alexandria until the 25th inst,

div.head: "TRAVIATA"
div.p: Yet another excellent performance thanks to Signorand Signora Coniglio. Singer Coniglio's conducting was better than ever, and the overture to the last act was encored, deservedly. Signora Coniglio was charming as Violetta : her grace and expressive features and her perfect voice combined to endow with real interest a part that can be dull if not trying. She is certainly a lyric soprano in the fullest sense, singing any note in reason (and avoiding those out of reason !) and every phrase with the utmost ease and fallness of tone. Signor Challis showed that he could play and sing the 'heavy father' as well as the barbaric king. This voice has a fine depth and tone. Signor Lanzerotti was annoying at the beginning, out of time, unduly affected, and always metallic; he seemed to be unable to produce any pleasing soft or low notes, and one felt that the endearments of his most charming lady love were ill deserved. But he improved towards the finish most distinctly. All the minor parts were really good, and the chorus was excellent. I see they are controlled and most energetic: ally controlled--from the prompter's box. This gives Signor Coniglio time to devote his whole attention to the orchestra. By the way he really should be more merciful with the brass and wind 'instruments. One or two effects, faultless in point of time, were far too formidable as far as sound went. With the rest he is as good as one can wish for ; the violins seemed absolutely subject to his every movement, and yet he makes no exaggerated efforts. In costumes the Abbas went almost a century further back than the Khedivial Theatre. We may hope for a mediæval Traviata one of these days if at that røté But why did Violetta's maid wear ruch obviously modern clothes ? One remark I had been intending to make these many weeks. Why does the Abbas Theatre persistin having that appalling curtain, those soul-destroying, counter-jumpers and real ladies gyrating to the sound of a gramophone, and against it all the names of those great singers on either side. It should be publicly burnt in the Opera Square and the ashes dropped into the Nile to slay the microbes of the sacred river. Surely someone in authority could be induced to "please note, and do the necessary."

div.head: "RIGOLETTO."
div.p: "Rigoletto" was quite admirably given on Saturday night; in all the four-long acts there was not a moment without interest; it was really acted as well as sung, a most rare occurrence for an opera, that seems, if neglected, to be hopelessly old fashioned and faded The singers deserve full complement and honour, most of all perhaps Signor Gregoretti as Rigoletto and Signor Ventura as the Duke. Sign. Gregoretti bas a fine dramatic baritone, and a thorough sense of the part to which he gave full effect Signor Ventura I am-anxious to hear again in many other parts; he evidently has distinct originality ; throughout he was the unscrupulous gallaót rather than the irresponsible gay youth, with a contempt evea of his own pleasures. He concentrated the whole part into the one song where it seems most hackneyed, the 'Douna E Mobili'; his treatment of the music was sheer cynical, trick work at certain moments, and the final phrase where he drew out the high note to an ultra pianis. simo and carried that through to the end of that phrase brought the house down ; he had to repeat it twice. Gilda-Signora Seinesenwas unconventional, especially in Caro Nome, and that again was a welcome change. For the rest her voice was quite pleasing, never sbrill or thin. The Bravo and his daughter, Signor Sabellico and Signora Prandi (I think that was her name) also acted and sang well to the part, and, so to speak, to their station in life. The chorus was quite gond as was the orchestra over whom Signor Coniglio seemed, as in "Aida,” to have the most complete com. mand. In a word it was a really excellent performance. It is a relief to hear and really. enjoy an opera and be able to praise it without hesitation Let us hope the standard set will be maintained all through the Abbas season.

Prince Waldemar of Prussia arrived here this morning with his suite and after breakfasting at the Winter Palace proceeded by the Hamborg and Anglo-American steamer "Mayflower” to Assouan, where he will stay at the Savoy Hotel for some weeks. Prince Waldemar is the eldest son of Prince Henry of Prussia and nephew of the Kaiser. He will stay at the Winter Palace on his return to Luxor at the end of February. Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst left yesterday afternoon after being here nearly two days. The Duke and Duchess of Devonshire attended divine service at the English church this morning. The chaplain, the Rev. A. W. Gross, very touchingly alluded in his sermon to the death of Miss Francis Collins which took place in church after evensong last Sunday as "a beautiful earthly ending to a most unselfish life.” The funeral which took place last Monday at the Protestant cemetery was attended by many visitors from the hotels and a large number of beautiful wreaths were sent by sympathising friends Professor Maspero the Director of the Cairo Museum has arrived at Luxor on his dahabeah going down stream. Sir George Scott Robertsob M.P., has arrived at the Winter Palace. Cool but delightful weather has succeeded the heat that came so suddenly a short time ago and is certainly much more seasonable and enjoyable.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke and Duchess of Madrid, who arrived this morning at Alexandria. by the "Heliopolis" were received on board the steam or by the Governor, representing the Khedive. Their Highnesses drove direct to the New Khedivial Hotel and will leave tomorrow for Cairo by a special train. The Barl of Rothes and Mr. Crighton, who have been staying at the Grand Hotel Kbar room, have gone for a shooting trip up the Blue Nile. The Earl of Kingston and Sir Robert Harvey have also started on an expedition after big game, travelling up the White Nile in a private steamer Mrs Spead has passed throagh Cairo ona visit to Mr. and Mrs. Aitkin at Minieh. Sir Joseph Sabs Pasha has been appointed Managing Director of the Cairo Water Cy.. Sir Joseph will leave Alexandria at the end of the month to enter into his new daties on 1st February Lady Oppenheimer bine decided to spend the rest of the season at Al Hayat, Helouan. Mr. P. B. J. Hernebyk, J. P, 0. R S. Consel for Japan at Liverpool, is also making a lenghthy stay at Al Hayat. Mr. Frouk Cook, of the firm' of Mossrs. Thomas Cook and Sons, will visit Egypt early next mouth. Captain McDanbar, 20th Lancers, who was until his marriage A.D.C. to General Bullock, is shortly to take up the adjataney of the Imperial Yeomanry. The funeral took place this morning in Cairo of the late Mrs. 8. M. Amos. Among those who attended were Mr. Alban, Johnson Pasha and Mrs Jonhson, Mr.and Mrs W.Carey, Mr. Rowlatt, Mr. Graham, Mr. Lyons, Mr. Scott-Moncrieff, and Dr. and Mrs. Roffor.

div.head: A. R. M. A. D. S.
div.p: DANCE AT SAVOY PALACE

As announced in our issue of yesterday the Alexandria and Ramleh Amateur Musical and Dramatic Society held most successful dance on Monday evening at the Savoy Palace Hotel. The Savoy Palace, which is truly palatial in design, is an ideal spot for any form of feativity, and, beyond the great advantage of the natural adaptability of the building to entertainments, the liberal catering of the management, the eagerness of one and all of the staff to meet every desire of those whom they entertain, and especially of the manager whose ability is almost marvellous, ensure the complete satisfaction of their guests. On Monday evening the Society entertained some hundred members of the Alexandria and Ramleh communities and all were pleased with the fare provided them. The luxurious winter-garden and magnificently designed diuing-hall with their plethora of electric globes presented quite a gay scene, and in one corner of the winter Rr. den was a buffet lavish both in quality and quantity. The floor of the ball room, though perhaps & trifle heavy, had been given an excellent surface and Mr. D'Ambra's well known orchestra made dancing a great ples. sure. The room was at no time too crowded ; unfortunately the dancing men were rather too scaree, but this was the only drawback of the evening. The hour of two a.m. Was well past before the most enthusiastic devotees at the shrine of Terpsichore left the ball room. At midnight the greater number of the party sat down to an excellent supper, there being several parties given. To enumerate all those present would occupy more space than we bare at our disposal; but we might mention the following names :1 H.E. Mustapha Pacha Ibadi, Governor of Alexandria, Bened ucci Bey And Mr. Benedaoci. Mr. and Mrs. Douglas · Allen, Mr. Donald Allen, Mr. Allen, Mr. Angel, Miss Bell, Mr. H. O. Bennett, Capt. J. REDUCED PRICES
- ETHIOPIAN RAILWAY COMPANY.
PARIS, January 21, The liquidator of the late Ethiopian Rail way Company has been authorised to concorde the line and concession to the nea Society formed by France and Ethiopia. (Havas

Paris, January 22. The Commercial Tribunal of the Seine ba authorised the transfer of the old Ethiopian Railway Company to a fresh Company which must be approved by the French and Abyski nian Governments in return for its assets the old company will receive compensation enabling it to pay an annual dividend of frabo for woh bond. Its creditors will receive a 60 % quota of the bet profits of the new company.
(Reuter)
CABINET CHANGES

LONDON, January 21. Mr. Lawson Walton's death has revived the rumours of Cabinet changes. Mr. Gladstone would be raised to the peerage and be succeed ed by Sir W. S. Robson. Mr Rufos Isaac would be made Attorney General, though the libernila are apprehensive of the possibility of a Jabour candidate contesting Mr. Evans sent in view of the Mid-Devon result, which has stimulated interest in the pending elec tions at Woroester, and South Leeds. (Rotster)
JAPAN'S BUDGET..

TOKIO, January 21. The budget shows postponements of various navy, army and other expenditures and an increase in taration amounting to 11,000,000 yen, in order to place the finanone of the coun try in a sound position. It empowers the issue of loan of 39,000,000 yen for reproductive works.
(Reuter
SIR H. FOWLER'S SPEECH.

LOVDON, January 21. Sir Henry Fowler, speaking at Wolverhampton, denied the rumours of dissensions in the Cabinet He said he would oppose Socialem to the attermost. He predicted that the coming session would be a hard one. The chief mea sure would be a licensing bill. The Government would also deal with the education question and old age pensions.
(Reuter)
GERMANY'S UNEMPLOYED
+ BERLIN, January 21. A fight has taken place between the unem ployed and the police in front of the Reichstag. The police charged with swords. Numbers of
unemployed were wounded in the head. A de monstration by the unemployed at Hanover resulted in wh attack on the police with knives.
(Router
HULL LABOUR CONFERENCE

LONDON, January 21. The Hall Labour Conference bas rejected the resolution to amend the principles of the party with a view to overthrowing capitalism and introducing public ownership, by 951,000 votes to 91,000. Other sccialistic motions were rejected by similar majorities. (Reuter)
TURKISH TROOPS TO MOBOLISE
. ST. PETERSBURG, January 21. The Bourse Gazette learn from Bake that the Turkish troops on the Persian frontier bave been ordered to mobolise. The reserves will be called out.
(Reiter)
CRICKET
ENGLAND AND TASMANIA.
LAUNCESTON, January 21. England beat Tasmania by 190 runs
(Reuter)
THE MOROCCAN SITUATION.
Paris, January 21. General d'Amade telegraphs that the Me balla is making on Berreshid. (Havas)
TANGIER, January 21. The Oueazan authorities have proclaimed Sultan Moulay Hafid.
(Haras)
TANGIER, January 21. There are now 2,000 French troops in Rabat and vicinity.
(Reuter)
A TRAIN DISASTER.
Mtlax, January 21 Three trains collided at Acquabella. 9 persons were killed and 25 injured. (Hans)
TRIAL OF SIGNOR NASI.
* Rome, January 22. The Senate has resumed the trial of Signor Nasi.
(Reuter)
LORD CROMER AND FREE-TRADE.
LONDON, January 22. Mr. Wintson Churchill, speaking at Man chester, welcomed Lord Cromer to the ranks of the Free-traders.
(Reuter
ITALIAN ANARCHISTS.
ARRESTED.
NEW YORK, January 21. Three Italians have been arrested at Rio de Janeiro. They are suspected to be members of the band of Anarchists who were attempting to blow up the American squadron. (Router)
EXCAVATIONS IN UPPER EGYPT (From Our Ows CORBESPONDENT.)

• Assouan, Jan 18 Dr. Zucker who has been excavating on Elephantine Island has finished his work there and is now at Kom Ombo where he hopes to make some discoveries in the necropolis be tween the temple and Sir Ernest Cassel's estate

Professor Ma-pero the famous archaeologist and director of the Cairo Museum is on his Lihabeah between the cataract and recently visited Abu Simpel to see if the head of one of the colossi hefore the temple could be raised and placed in its original position. A portion of the body is missing and diggings will be made in the sand with a view to its recovery. If it is found there will be no difficulty in placing the head in position.
Symo interesting work is going on at Kala basis, where the temple is being restored and strenghthened against the inundation that will como after the raising of the dam. It is sad

to think that the pretty new houses built on the river banks about here to replace the old ones which were submerged when the barrage was completed will also be under water and their owners must more once more go to a higher level.
INTERNATIONAL CONGRESS OF

RELIGIONS In 1900 the first "International Congress for the History of Religions" was held in Paris, and the next took place in Basle tyor years later. Arrangements are now being made for the third to be held at Oxford in September, from the 15th to 18th inclusive. The congress will deal with the religions of Mexico and Perap of the Chinese and Japanese, the Egyptians, the Semites, India and Iran, the Greeks and Romans, the Germans, Celts, and Slave, and the Christians The congress is completely unsectarian, and most comprehensive, its fondamental rule provid. ing that the discussions shall be of an esser tially bistorical character, and that addresses dealing with dogma or personal conviction are prohibited. The local committee has sub representative members as Dr. Vernon Bartlet, Dr. Edward Caird, Professor Cheyne, Mr. P. C. Conybeare, Professor Driver, Professor Percy. Gardver, Dr. G. Buchanan Gray, Rev. Professor Margoliouth, Dr. Gilbert Murray, Rev. Dr. Rasbdall, Professor Sanday, Professor Sayoe, Dr. Arthur Sidgwick, Professor Tylor, and Principal Estlin Carpenter.

div.head: MACEDONIAN REFORM.
div.p: • We extract the following from the "Tribune":

Two statements may be safely made about Macedonia first that the programme of reforms submitted by Lord Lansdowne has produced valuable results; second, that they are altogether inadequate for the purpose for which they were intended.

The most valuable of the reforms accomplished regards the financial administration of the country. Civil servants are now more te galarly paid than before, and as a consequence more work can be extracted from them. The Finance Commission includes excellent men, and is introducing order into the collection and administration of taxes. Its action is purely beneficial. The gendarmery also is slowly de ve oping. In the provinces, which are spoken of collectively as Macedonia there are forty: five foreign Officers, each of the five Great Powers having a district assigned to & general officer under General De Giorgis of its own nationality. In the English district gendarmery officers and men, the latter being Turkish subjeots, numher 800 ; in the Prettob-600; in the Austrian nearly 1,000'; in the Italian 1,000; while the Russians number 1,300.

The mere presence of this number of police officers throughout the country bass valuable effect, and, speaking generally, the officers not merely know their business, but are keen abont it. The trouble is, as was predicted in your columns eighteen months ago, that they are not permitted to exercise the authority which is needtul for gendariery work.

THE INTERNATIONAL MANDATES, The telegraph has already informed your readers of the latest attempt of the Turks to lessen the importance of the concessions already granted some of the foreign officers, from whom so much is expected, were engaged for three years This term is just about to expire. The Porte is willing to re-engage them provided that they will enter Turkish service. Experience shows that if they were to do so, in * few months they would become a useless for the purpose of reforms ordinary Torkish officials. By dint of pegging away, the Ambassadors, and notably Sir Nicholas O'Conor, may get a number of concessions granted, and with constant watchfulness put into execution, which will improve the gendarmery. In the same way by constant supervision be may súoceed in getting the financial provisions executed. But not all the Ambassadors combined can
ake the Turks willingly make the gendarme ry or the financial control & success

The step ander consideration at the present is that of the administration of law A certain mystery is observed with regard to it. But until the project of the Powers is made public it is sufficient to repeat that unless the proposed inspectors of the tribunuls are foreigners who are invested with power the reform will fail to exercise much beneficial influence.
While giving full value to the palliative measures which have been adopted, the fact remains that the condition of Macedonia is not more satisfactory thau it was three years

A certain mystery 18 observed with regard to it. But until the project of the Powers is made public it is sufficient to repeat that unless the proposed inspectors of the tribu ods are foreigners who are invested with power the reform will fail to exercise much beneficial influence

While giving full vàlue to the palliative measures which have been adopted, the fact remains that the condition of Macedonia is not more satistactory thau it was three years ago In some respects, indeed, it is worse, hecause it is complicated by the struggles between dierent Christian races Life and property remain largely without protection. In many districts the murders committed by Moslems are appalling. Not less appalling are those committed by Greek and Bulgarian bands.

PANDEMONIUM IN THE BALKANS The civil war between the Greeks and Bulgarians is, indeed, a disgrace to all parties concerned. Turkey, of course, abould receive the chief blame, because her first duty was, and is, to keep order and protect lite and property. She has not done either. She is responsible for the continued existence of Greek and Bulgarian bands It is unnecessary to inquire whether she encouraged the entry and formation of Greek bands, because, whether or not, it is certain that she could have put a stop to their operations if she had so chosen. In like manner if she had | attacked the Bulgarian bands no Power in Europe would have blamed her. The civil war between Greeks and Bulgarians is a dis grace to the Powers who have not insisted upon the Porte taking steps to put an end to it

The want of statesmanship shown both by Bulgarians and Greeks during the last three Vears is colossal. A Stambouloff and & Tricoupis, bad they been at the head of their respentive countries, would long ago have found a modus vivendi and would have pas an end to the mad strife between their countrymen in Macedonis itself. As far as I have been able to learn, no attempt bas been made to such purpose in either country. Insteal, there is a silly war of words, in which the Greeks have been the worst offenders. Let! it be added that I entirely recognize that the Greeks have an important interest in Mace denia, and that their rights ought to be carefully respected. Bulgaria would be content with, good government of an autonomous character, Greece, so far as her desires can be known, wishes the partition of Macedonia. Apparently no Power is prepared even to examine such & proposal Autonomy ought to satisfy her also..

The Next Move. We are now waiting for the next-move of the Powers. What strikes observers here is the smallness of the results which have been obtained for the large amount of Ambassadorial energy expended. In addition to diplomatic labour & naval demonstration had to be made to obtain certain financial reforins which every honest adviser of the Sultan must have been in a position to explain were for the benefit of his Government. Surely moré ought to have come forth after euch heavy labont.

It is indisputable that so far the reforms decreed by the Porte are inadequate. Everyone feels tht either Macedonia must be left to bleed to death or a bilder oorse, one worthy of the traditions of British statorneo, and especially of Gladstone, must be adopted.

The Pilgrime Store

The pilgrim saison is now at an end. Quite a number of abips passed here lately en route to Jedda The Padhli Sultan Hoosin Bin Ahmed, recently lett here by the Italian ateamer, P. Gioni, for Monsaws en route to Jedda The brother of the Sultan of Labej, Mohsin bin Padh), has also lefton'a piligrimage to Meoca. slege of Sana.

I think I informed you in a previous letter of the decision of the Turkish authorities to punish those officials who neglected their duties at Sana during the siege. Sixteen officers have now been arrested and ordered to be banished out of the Turkish empire. They were taken to Hodeida for embarkation, and on their way they gave trouble on the road and set fire to a coffee shop at Bagel. Wrook of a Vool

News bas just been received that the sainbook Rahala, which left here a few days ago for Hodeida with a mixed cargo of merchandise, four, and species, has been wruokal somewbere between Hodeida and Muchs, and is a total loss The sufferers are all Arab and lodian merchaita of Aden. The estimated value of the goods is 18 50,000, including about $ 29,000 worth of spe
Nothing has been heard of the fate of the Nokbada and men on board the ship who numbered about ten. Rald at Zaboed.

We have not had much news lately from ZAbeed, owing to the disturbed state of tho.cara van routes between Moeba and Zaheed. A gang of Beduin robbers raided Rebeedat night & sbort time ago, but the inhabitants having got inter mation about them, fired at them, killing two of them and tbe rest escaped.

In spite of the establishment of military posts between Hodeida and Sana, insecurity.on those cars van routes still prevails more or lessAbout ten camels loaded with goods for Sana have been killed by the men of the Imam and the goods plundered.

div.head: PROTECTION. AGAINST CHOLERA
div.p: In addition to the Coast Guard cruiser "Abdel Moneim" at present actually patrolling the Red Sea, in order to prevent dhows cross ing with Sudanese pilgrims, coastguards and camel cors are as well patrolling the whole length of the Suez Canal banks, for fear of pilgrims escaping the Tor quarantine. Quaran tine doctors and officers have been stationed at the pontion bridge caravan stations at Bakr and Kantars, with instructious to examine everyone crossing the Canal from Arabia A large number of porters with carts are embark ing for. Tor, for the desimbarking of the pilgrims There, who at present are on their way back from Mecca.

div.head: PROPOSED EUROPEAN COTTON PLANTATION IN AMERICA.
div.p: The Committee of the International Cotton Congress, at a meeting in Manchester last week, approved the principle of the proposal to pur chane a cotton plantation in the United States, to be controlled by a European company, '88 the speediest means of briuging about, in the interets of the cotton industry of the world, the reforms advocated at all the international cutton congresses. They will invite the members of their associations to take an interest in the proposed company.

div.head: SAVOY-HOTEL
div.p: The Prince and Princesa Tenno who arrived with Mrs.Aahay daughter of Sie est maal, by the "Hohenzollen," were met at Alexandria by H. E. Mohamed Zoki Paahi who travelled to Cairo in their company. They are now 0000pying one of the finest suites of Apartments at the Savoy where Sir Ernest Cassel and others of his party are expected on Wednesday, Sir Ernest Cassel is travelling by the "Heliopolis", bet acother of his honoured guests, Mr. Jacob Sobiff the well known American financier in expected the same day by the "Cedrio." Other late arrivals at the Savoy are Count Puany Hoyrus who travelled by the Austrian Lloyd, Mr. and Mrs. Kingham who have come from Alexandria for a few days, Major and indy Evelyn Collius who have returned trom their trip up river, and Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Murpby.

The bookings for this week at the Savoy Aro enormous, and the demand for the finest suites of rooms is almost unprecedented. Mr. and Lady Marjory Binney and Captain and Mrs. Rose are expected. back from Upper Egypt, as are Captain and Mrs. Doveuish, and the other new arrivals include Baron Philip Schley with the Baloness (née Rothschila) for whom a large suite has been reserved, and Mrs. and Mise Campbell Slater who will be accompanied by Miss Sybil Campbell of Stan field. These are expauted by the "Heliopolis as are Mr. and Mrs. E. G. B. Biddle, who have been in Egypt in past years, Mr. Greve who has erected one of the handsoment buildingo in Chicago and Mr. and Mrs. W. B. Poltz
Another large suite of rooms has been reserved for Mr. Louis G. Tiffany of New York and his party, who are expected by the

Caronis" to-day. Mme Wanamaker and her party will arrive by the same boat, as will Mr. E C. Converse the big New York financier who will be accompained by Mrs. and Miss Converse and by Miss Edith Dunshee.
Mr. and Mrs W. B Potta from New York, And Mr. R. W. Patterson from the same city who is also bringing a party, are amongst those travelling by the "Cedric."

Mr. and Mrs Jordan Duquares are expected by P. and O., Mr. and Mr. Chas. Stewart Smith are also due in a day or 80 ; and rooms bave been booked from the 23rd for Mr. and Mrs. George C. Oliver and the Misses Oliver of Wartnaby Hall, Melton Mowbray.

Apartments have also been reserved for Mr. And Mrs. Craddock whose marriage took place less than a fortnight ago at Shanklin. He is in the 2nd Life Guards. Mrs. Craddock (nee Old ham) is tall, dark and very bandsome, and from all accounts their wedding must have been a singularly picturesque one. ". In view of the numbers who are expected at
the Savoy on Saturday evening, the manage ment asks as a favour that guests arriving after dinner in time for the dance will kindly présent their cards of invitation if requested to do so.

div.head: SLEEPING SICKNESS CONFERENCE
div.p: The second International Sleeping sickness Conference which was to have met at the Poreigo Office last Thursday has been further postponed, this time at the request of the French Government, which is still considering the instructions to be given to its deleRates Probably the meeting will take place in course of February

From an authoritative British source Router's Agency learns that the latest investigations into this terrible scourge reveal DO startling development. The hopes which were at first entertained as to the efficacy of medical treatment by the injection of atoxyl have have not so far been altogether realized.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Mercredi, 22 Janvier

La tendance de ces jours passés s' entue, c'est dire que l'ensemble de la oote ost fermo et en hausse, mais que les transactiona se raréfient et se limitent, da moins comme importanoo, une petite catégorie de valeurs. Les titres lourds sont en général négligés, sauf la Dalra venue en hausse de Londres et l'Obligation Crédit Poncier qui jouit d'une grando vogue locale. Le Comptoir et la Delta Land sont plas faibles, tandis que la Building Lands progresse de 1 3/8 à 11/2 faute de vendeurs. A sigrialer encore une demande de Paris en Land Bank et des achats du Caire en Estates. L'Union Foncière été également traitée. En Banques, l'Agricole a été négligée et National soutenue, mais sans affaires. La ten dance de l'ensemble reste favorable.

L'Obligation Crédit Foncier, qui a été ce matin le principal objet de l'attention a passé de 293 À 304 l'ancienne et de 258 a 2594 la nouvelle. La Dalra a avancé de son obté de 18 11/16 & 141/16, en sympathie avec Londres.

Des demandes ont également poussé la Delta Light de 99/16 a 9 5/8, l'Alexandris Water de 10 5/16 A 10 3/8, les Eaux du Caire de 100 à 104 les actions de capital et de 174 à 177 les actions de jouissance, la Land Bank de 7 1 9 79716 et le Banco de Roma do 108 à 108 1/2.

D'autre part, sur des offres persistantes, les Bière d'Mlexandrie continuent à fléchir de 103 a 100 loe Privilégiées et de 65 a 60 les Divi dendes. La Banque d'Athènes réactionne aussi de 119 à 118 1/2, les Nungovich Hotels de 13 1/4 à 13, l'Union Foncière de 1 1/2 à 4 7/16, et la Banque d'Orient de 118 & 117.

En titres d'ordre secondaire, la Salt and Soda avane de 14/3 à 14/6, les Sacrerios de 33 a 35 et les Marketa do 84 24/3, tandis que le Comptoir rétrogrado de 2 9/32 à 2 7/32, l'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 18/6 18k et la fondateur United de 1/2 à 7/16.
Il n'y a pas d'autre changement à signaler.
On remet en circulation l'idée du rétablissement du marché au terme. Mais on attend sans doute uno reprise sérieuse des affaires pour prendre a co sajet une décision définitive

div.head: MUNICIPALITE D'ALEXANDRIE
div.p: AVIS

Le Samedi 25 Janvier 1908 de 10 heures du matin à midi, la Municipalité proodders à la vente aux enchères pabliques près de la Porte Rosette d'une quantité de pierres (Kantaris, Moellons, Dakchoums) provenant de la démolition des Fortifications Sud.
Ces pierres sont divisées en lots de 20 a +100 m3.

Les acheteurs devront payer le droit d'en cbère de 1 % et déposer le 10 % de la valeur de la marobandise achetée au moment de la vente et cffectuer le paiement intégral a la Caisse Municipalo, le lendemain da jour de l'adjudication.

Ils auront A supporter les droits de carrière au profit de la Ville et devront enlever les pierres achetées dans un délai de dix jours nous peine de folle enchère pour compte de l'adjudicataire et de perte du dépot de 10%
L'Administrateur, (Signé) W. P. CHATAWAY. Alexandrie le 18 Janvier 1908. 81795-3-2
AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la fourniture du Charbon de terre néoessaire à ses services durant l'année 1908
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE: 30(Trente.)
Le cahier des charges est déposé au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sons pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 4 Février 1908.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour à 5h. p m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention "Soumission po fourniture Charbon de terre."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges devra être remis séparéinent au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 4 février à midi.
Toute offre qui'ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dess03 sera «cartée Alexandrie, le 18 Janvier 1908.
L'Administrateur 31794-8-1
(Signe) W.P. CHATAWAY. AVIS
La Municipalité met en adjudication la pose et fourniture d'une voie Decauville pour l'abattoir du Mex. Le cautionnement est fixé à LB.60 (Soixante).
Le cahier des charges est dépose au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 11 Février 1908.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation le même jour a 5 h. p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention : "Soumission pour Voie Decauville pour l'abattoir du Mex.11

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Général, avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 11 Février 1908 à inidi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée. Alexandrie, le 21 Janvier 1908.
L'Administrateur 81805-3-1
(Signé) W.P CHATAWAY. AVIS
La Municipalito met en adjudication la fourniture des tuyaux en grès et accessoires nécessaires à son service.
Le cautionnement est fixé à L.E. 60 (Soixante).
Le cahier des charges est dépoa6 au bureau Technique où il peut être consulté par les intéress s tous les jours de 9h à midi, les jours fériés except 8.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté Monsieur l'administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 11 Février 1908.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Dél-gation Je même jour à 5 h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porten en outre la men tion : "Soumission pour fourniture tuyaux en grès.

Le cantionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis B parément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 11 Février à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écarte. Alexandrie, le 21 Janvier 1908.
L'Administrateur 31804-3-1 (Signd) W. P. CHATAWAY

div.head: Adminletration des Chemins de for
div.p: de l'Etat

AVIS L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du Public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au deux Mars, 1908, & midi au plus tard des offres pour la fourniture d'articles de quincaillerie pour portes, fenêtres et men bles, rigoureusement conformes aux échantillons-types de l'Administration qui peuvent etre examinés aux Magasins Généraux de Boulao (Caire) chaque jour de neuf beures da matin à une heure p.m., les Dimanches et jours fériés exceptés.

Cette fourniture doit être faite conform - ment aux termes et conditions do Cabier des Charges dont on peut obtenir un exam plaite contre paiement de 900 m/m (deux cents millièmes), chaque jour et aux même beures qoo oi-dessus, au Service Central des Magasius Boulac (Caire) et au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur dee Magasins do Gabbary (Alexandrie).

Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication, devrs en même temps qu'elle présentera son offre et sous peine de ballité de celle-ci, déposer à la Caisse Centrale do l'Administration au Caire, un cautionnement provisoire, de la valeur de L E. 25 (Livres Egyptiennes vingt eing) ou se confor mer aux prescriptions de l'article XI da Cahier des Charges.

Les offres doivent être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de trenta millimes, ainsi que d'une copie du reça (ou des autres doclimenta en original) constatant le verso ment ou la mise à la disposition de l'Administration da cautionnement provisoire. Elles seront adressées par la poste sous pli recommandé à :
Monsieor le Directeur Général des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Caire (Egypte) et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
"Offre pour la fourniture de Quincaillerie"
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve lo droit de diviser la commande.
Le Caire, le 6 Janvier 1908. 31699-2-2
